summary.para: One or more options of , followed by at most one option that takes values, should be accepted when grouped behind one '-' delimiter.

When true, the following are equivalent.
-abcXyellow -abcX=yellow -abcX:yellow -abc -X=yellow -ab -cX=yellow -a -b -c -Xyellow -a -b -c -X yellow -a -b -c -X=yellow -a -b -c -X:yellow
This defaults to true unless an option with a short name of two or more characters is added.

member.name: P:McMaster.Extensions.CommandLineUtils.CommandLineApplication.OptionsComparison
member.summary: The way arguments and options are matched.

summary.para: One or more options of , followed by at most one option that takes values, should be accepted when grouped behind one '-' delimiter.

When true, the following are equivalent.
-abcXyellow -abcX=yellow -abcX:yellow -abc -X=yellow -ab -cX=yellow -a -b -c -Xyellow -a -b -c -X yellow -a -b -c -X=yellow -a -b -c -X:yellow
This defaults to true unless an option with a short name of two or more characters is added.

member.name: P:McMaster.Extensions.CommandLineUtils.CommandLineApplication.OptionNameValueSeparators
member.summary:
Characters used to separate the option name from the value.
By default, allowed separators are ' ' (space), :, and =
member.remarks: Space actually implies multiple spaces due to the way most operating system shells parse command line arguments before starting a new process.

member.name: P:McMaster.Extensions.CommandLineUtils.CommandLineApplication.ValueParsers
member.summary:
Gets the default value parser provider.
The value parsers control how argument values are converted from strings to other types. Additional value parsers can be added so that domain specific types can converted. In-built value parsers can also be replaced for precise control of all type conversion.
Value parsers are currently only used by the Attribute API.

summary.para: Defines the working directory of the application. Defaults to .
This will be used as the base path for opening response files when is true.

member.name: F:McMaster.Extensions.CommandLineUtils.CommandOptionType.MultipleValue
member.summary:
The option can be specified multiple times.
Example input: --letter A --letter B --letter C

member.name: F:McMaster.Extensions.CommandLineUtils.CommandOptionType.SingleValue
member.summary:
The option can only be specified once.
Example input: --letter A
Example input: --letter=A
Example input: --letter:A

member.name: F:McMaster.Extensions.CommandLineUtils.CommandOptionType.SingleOrNoValue
member.summary:
The option can only be specified once, and may or may not have a value.
To disambiguate this from , values provided cannot be space-separated from the option name, but must use '=' or ':'
Example input: --log
Example input: --log:verbose

member.name: F:McMaster.Extensions.CommandLineUtils.CommandOptionType.NoValue
member.summary:
The option can only be specified once, and does not have a value.
Example input: --no-commit

summary.para: Specifies options for how to handle response files. The parser treats arguments beginning with '@' as a file path to a response file.

A response file contains additional arguments that will be treated as if they were passed in on the command line. Response files can have comments that begin with the # symbol. You cannot use the backslash character (\) to concatenate lines.

member.name: F:McMaster.Extensions.CommandLineUtils.ResponseFileHandling.Disabled
member.summary: Do not parse response files or treat arguments with '@' as a response file

summary.para: Multiple arguments may appear on one line. Arguments are separate by spaces.
Double and single quotes can be used to wrap arguments containing spaces.
Each line in the file is treated as an argument, regardless of whitespace on the line.
Lines beginning with # are skipped.
